definitions.definition: to break without dividing into separate parts; to break something in this way

examples.text: The ice cracked as I stepped onto it.
He has cracked a bone in his arm.
The dish had cracked quite badly.
The leather/​mud/​paint/​plaster had cracked.

definitions.definition: to break open or into pieces; to break something in this way

examples.text: A chunk of the cliff had cracked off in a storm.
His face cracked into a smile.
to crack a nut
She cracked an egg into the pan.

definitions.definition: to hit something/somebody in a short hard manner

examples.text: I cracked my head on the low ceiling.
He cracked me on the head with a ruler.
He stood up suddenly, cracking his head on the low ceiling.
As I leapt up, I cracked my skull on a beam and passed out.

definitions.definition: to make a sharp sound; to make something do this

examples.text: A shot cracked across the ridge.
He **cracked his whip** and galloped away.

definitions.definition: if your voice cracks, it changes in depth, volume, etc. suddenly and in a way that you cannot control

examples.text: In a voice cracking with emotion, he told us of his son's death.

definitions.definition: to no longer be able to function normally because of pressure

examples.text: Things are terrible at work and people are cracking under the strain.
They questioned him for days before he cracked.
The old institutions are cracking.
She is under a lot of pressure but is showing no signs of cracking.
The stresses of his job became too great and he finally cracked.

definitions.definition: to find the solution to a problem, etc; to find the way to do something difficult

examples.text: to crack the enemy’s code
After a year in this job I think **I've got it cracked**!
‘How's the investigation going?’ ‘I think we've cracked it.’
A team of experts finally cracked the code.
We need some more solid evidence if we're going to crack the case.

definitions.definition: to find a way of stopping or defeating a criminal or an enemy

examples.text: Police have cracked a major drugs ring.

definitions.definition: to open a bottle, especially of wine, and drink it
to use your authority or power to make somebody work very hard, usually by treating them in a strict way

examples.text: This entertainer can crack wise with the best of them.

definitions.definition: to begin immediately and work quickly

examples.text: There's a lot to be done, so let's get cracking.

definitions.definition: a difficult problem or situation to deal with
not as good as people say

examples.text: He's not nearly such a good writer as he's cracked up to be.

definitions.definition: to use more force than is necessary

wordOrigin: Old English cracian ‘make an explosive noise’; of Germanic origin; related to Dutch kraken and German krachen. Sense (8) of the noun is from Irish craic ‘entertaining conversation’.
